Managing blood sugars when you’re struggling to eat
How does everyone manage their blood sugars when they are struggling to eat due to either illness or something else?

comments.text: I drink ginger ale and try to keep it down as long as possible. If I have to I turn off the pump
It would depend. Are your sugars high or low?
I sip juices and gingerale, snack lightly on crackers or toast. A little something here or there is better than nothing.
Assuming your basal dose is correct, you shouldn't need to eat.

My diabetic nurses told me that ice cream is the best option. It is easy to consume and is easy to calculate the carbs for. Other than that use crackers if you’re feeling nauseous. Hope you feel better!

If you're dropping low you can mix up a batch of glucagon and take small doses for up to 24 hours with a regular insulin syringe instead of the included pig-sticker in the kit. It's kept me out of the hospital more than once when I was sick and couldn't keep much down. It's off-label, but endos are using it more often nowadays. Do a search on glucagon mini dosing for more info.
If I can't bring myself to eat anything at all, I will up my temp basal to like 25% or so.  My problem is that my liver dumps glucose after not eating for awhile.

How much insulin for pasta?
Hey everyone! I'm still learning how to count carbs to insulin ratio. I'm having pasta tonight (on vacation) and it's a lot of carbs! Would the standard 10:1 ratio work for this? The pasta is 140 carbs, although I doubt I'll eat it all. Current BS is 120. Thanks for any advice!

comments.text: If the sauce is super fatty (cheesy) and there’s a lot of protein in the sauce (meat sauce) it’ll slow down your body’s absorption of the glucose from the pasta. In these cases I typically do a little less so I don’t plummet, knowing that I’ll need to do a second round of insulin in ~3-5 hours when it starts going back up again.

What’s a standard ratio? Is that ratio specific to you? If so then ok, if it’s not then I don’t know. Is there a sauce with what ingredients? Are you very new to bolusing? If so please send stick with your endo recommendations and err on the side of caution. For any new foods I try I generally eat a small amount and make a note of anything I may need to adjust with my bolus.

Trial and error my friend. Make your best educated guess using your carb ratios you have used in the past and eat a measured amount. Then take notes on what your blood sugar does afterwards. Then when you eat it again, adjust how much insulin you take according to what you learned from last time. 

We do this with just about everything and after a few years we have gotten remarkably good at guesstimating carb counts. Even without scales or carefully measured portions.

It also depends on the type of pasta. For example 100g of durum wheat pasta (if weighed before cooking) like penne, spaghetti and farfalle are around 72 carbs on average, whilst fresh pasta like tagliatelle is around 54 carbs per 100 g. Whole-wheat pasta usually has less carbs than average durum wheat pasta (around 65 carbs per 100 g on average). Then you have to consider the type of sauce of course, plus you need to consider that if you're eating at a restaurant the meal is usually richer in fats and the portions tend to be bigger. The usual carb ratio should work just fine, but we're all different so you can't know unless you try.

With a pasta load that big be careful when injecting all at once. As previous poster mentioned sauce with lots of fat can slow down absorption. Sometimes you can go low (and have to treat the low) before sky rocketing up later.
All of it. And then more 2 hours later.
All of it

Pasta is tricky because it takes a while for your body to start absorbing it, so I normally give 20-30 percent of insulin before eating, then about 1.5 hours later I give the rest. That’s what works for me, but everyone’s body is different so it’s good to try different things!

Can insulin cause hunger?
I was diagnosed with type 1 almost 3 years ago. Back then I was an emotional overeater, so I weighed around 100kg, though I was never really that hungry.

But oh my good lord am I hungry now. I weigh around 60kg now, but I still eat like I weigh 100. Every time I eat, I take insulin, but every time I take insulin, my hunger increases.

Sometimes I just don't feel like dealing with hunger, so I only drink water that day, and that's all I consume. And I'm nowhere near as hungry as I am when I take my insulin like I'm supposed to. I can eat until I'm so full I feel like puking, and yet, as soon as I take insulin I get hungry within 15 minutes.

Long story short, I'm going insane with all this hunger. And I'm so tired of this evil cycle of eating > taking insulin > getting hungry > eating > taking insulin > getting hungry > eating > etc.

I take Novorapid and Tresiba, I don't know how many countries they're available in, but I really need to know if anyone else is dealing with this.

I'm a grown man, and I'm not afraid to admit that I sometimes get so frustrated from the hunger that I start crying. I just want to feel full for more than 5 minutes.

comments.text:
i have the same freaking problem but i just thought it was because im not eating the right stuff or because im chub. i eat until my stomach literally hurts and then not even 15 minutes later my stomach is GROWLING, but no matter what i eat (healthy or junk food) it still happens

i take admelog currently
you get hungry when your blood sugar goes lower, and insulin causes that.

Bro, it's pretty impressive that you shared this info, and that you went from 100kg to 60. I weigh ~100kg now and I'm trying to lose but it's so hard. I do feel like the more carbs I eat in a sitting, the more I want to eat later in the day after I inject. It's definitely frustrating. Also, T1 for 4 years.

Wish I could help more but maybe try low carb eating? Since you won't take as much insulin but you can still feel full.

I like cauliflower rice and meatballs and sugar free barbecue sauce. But definitely drink some water and have a small snack ready because the cauliflower doesn't satisfy for too long, but it's so low in calories it's awesome.

Yes. Insulin causes hunger and weight gain. You want to eat as few carbs as possible so that you do not need so much insulin. Try keto/low carb diet. You can eat cheese, bacon, meat, etc. all day without taking insulin.

Insulin does play a role in satiety, but it is not a main player. With that being said, insulin is actually anorexigenic, meaning it makes you feel not hungry. So it's unlikely that insulin is causing what you're experiencing.

However there is a possible link between insulin resistance and hunger. When you eat lots of high carb foods you end up craving them. It's like an itch, or an urge to keep eating them, not necessarily hunger. If you're feeling it after eating then it's probably this and not hunger. Insulin resistance in T1 is a dangerous game to play so I would talk to your Endo and see if there's anything going on. You may need to make dietary changes.

There is another possible explanation however. Our beta cells produce more than just insulin, they also make amylin. Since we're T1 we don't have working beta cells so we don't have amylin either. Amylin plays a role in regulating appetite. It suppresses it when you eat, so you begin to feel full and stop eating. Without amylin it is possible that you would not feel full.
The caveat here is that amylin is not the major player in satiety either. So it's unlikely to be having a very profound effect.

So while there are certainly some complications with appetite that are caused by having T1, they're normally not very extreme and most T1s will never really have any issues.

Source: degree in biochemistry


Edit: Hey OP I thought about it some more and wanted to add that based off your description I think what might be happening is postprandial spikes in blood sugar are causing your hunger. You mentioned it not being as bad if you don't eat at all, which made you associate it with the insulin you're taking when you eat. Which makes sense. But what I would wager is happening is you're eating and taking the insulin maybe just a little too late. This is making your blood sugar go way up right after you eat, but then plummeting back down awhile after because of the insulin. The high blood sugar makes you feel hungry and the plummeting afterwards exacerbates it. 

What kind of bolusing are you doing and when? I would suggest carefully trying to take your insulin sooner, even if that means you take it before eating. Hopefully this will help mellow out the "rollercoaster" you're experiencing and I bet it will help with your gnawing hunger pangs too!

I’ve been a type 1 diabetic since I was 12 and well I gained weight not directly bc of insulin, but bc of the hunger that comes with it so I understand where ur coming from. With time and effort it usually is the mental aspect of it.  I lost the weight and everything by controlling my food and portions and the next few months I was used to eating less and less without the hunger. 

Lessening your use of insulin makes you less hungry, so eating less carbs defo helps.

Adding on to another comment that was talking about amylin production... Some classes of drugs attempt to supplement amylin or perform similar functions. I definitely experience the hunger you're describing, and have also struggled with weight.

I took symlin for a while and it helped incredibly with not feeling hungry all the time. Unfortunately it also made me pretty nauseous and I eventually stopped taking it. Last year, I took Trulicity (off label for type 1 but provides some of the same effects) for about 6 months, and it was awesome... Was not feeling hungry all the time, and no nausea. Then I got pregnant so stopped taking it since it's not recommended during pregnancy. 

It's worth a conversation with your doctor to see about trying a supplemental hormone in that vein, and see if it helps you.

How do I get a pump? I'm not perfect.
Hey guys!

So I've read a ton of posts on this sub and others about people getting new pumps. I've asked my endocrinologist about it but she told me that in order to get a pump I need to have my blood sugars no lower than 85% in range for 30 days, with most days being 100% in range.

I think a pump would actually make my life a lot easier because I wouldn't be forgetting or missing shots. Nor would I be accidentally giving myself too much insulin.

I'm just wondering what you guys do to keep your sugars so in target to qualify for a pump? I've tried diets and crazy carb counting, but the only way I ever seem to get it close to 100% is by correcting my morning feet-to-floor syndrome and then basically not eating all day because eating will affect my blood sugar. But that leaves me hungry and generally in an awful mood all day.

I'm in Toronto Canada 🇨🇦

comments.text: Get a new doctor. Most go on pumps to get better control. If we were all that great on shots pumps wouldn’t be considered the standard of care for T1Ds. Btw my endo begged me to get on a pump to improve my bs when I was in college.
Always unpopular opinion, but stop eating carbs aside from non-starchy veggies.   Try it for 2 weeks.  If you aren't above 95%, go doctor shopping like the other guy suggested.

So in Manitoba pediatric care they require 3 consecutive a1cs under 10. I've never seen anything harder for requirements but damn yours takes the cake.

I know that our endo clinic is very conservative and want to make sure those on the pump know it's not a cure all for lowering a1c or dealing with issues you have from MDI. However I've known some who have successfully convinced the clinic to relax a bit with the following.  
1) researched and documented plan for which pump and why.  
2) printed academic articles stating that pumps are beneficial to those struggling with higher a1cs.  Use google scholar there are many available though you want to find free ones to print. 
3) concurrent use of cgm to monitor for lows. 
4) proof of Basal and carb ratio testing for different times of day. 

It's a lot of work, especially when other endos will just prescribe pumps easily. Also, if you are able to figure out how to build loop, you only need to find someone willing to part with dash pods to get started (though I wouldn't recommend as you won't know what to do for Basal rates at first).

I have never heard of such a thing.  I would, if possible, find a new endo.  You should be able to try a pump if you want to.

Also, you can actually give yourself too much insulin with a pump, if you enter the wrong carb amount.  

The pump works wonders for the Dawn Phenomenon and the "Feet to Floor" syndrome and can be a great tool that helps you deal with those.  

I personally prefer DMI and have about 85-87% in range with it but am on Omnipod because I promised my endo to give it a try.  There are benefits to both, but if the morning glucose rises are the things holding you back from better control, I would push to try it.

Holy shit I hate that approach! A pump, or new pump makes control easier. Withholding a script for a new pump is bullshit! I’d give him a piece of my mind, then switch docs. I’m so tired of the state of healthcare. F$&K!
Back in 2000 when I first got mine the only caveat was how often I was willing to prick my fingers. If you already have a CGM it should be a no brainer.

No offense but your Endo is a quack. The idea of getting on a pump is to best regulate blood glucose. Unless there’s something in the Canadian healthcare system? 

You could contact the pump company (I just started on the Omnipod with my Dexcom, and I highly recommend it!!) and ask them directly- they are sales reps highly motivated to help you navigate the process.

Also, if there is an organization to whom you can report this Endocrinologist, incredibly poor medicinal advice, I would try to do so. If they’re saying this to you, they’re saying this to God knows how many other diabetics and giving them terrible advice as well.

I went to a brand new endo and said “hey my son is getting on a pump, I haven’t seen a doctor in over 7 years for my diabetes, can you please write me a prescription and put a rush so I can start around the same time as him?” And she said “of course! I’ll check on you in 3 months…” got my pump about 8 days later.

100% agree with everyone who says get a new doctor.  We got my son on a pump days before he turned 3 years old and 5 months after diagnosis.  No way were we in the 85% at that point.  His endo wanted us to have time to learn the basics and be comfortable giving shots and finger pokes so that if any of his tech failed, we could go back to MDI no problem.  That was our only requirement before getting a pump.  It has definitely helped with getting and keeping him in range.  It’s also easier to dose or check and see if you did for those times that you just can’t remember if you did or not.  Having a pump has been a game changer for all of us (as well as the Dexcom).  

I am not a resident of Canada, so I can’t offer any advice in regards to getting one there.  But, I will say that fighting to get a pump is worth it.  My son started on the Tslim Control IQ and is now on the Omnipod 5.   Both are great and helped keep him in range.  We started on the Tslim because it was the only one at that time that directly communicated with his CGM.  We switched to the Omnipod 5 when it offered the same, because it meant no more fanny packs and no more tubes for a now active 5 year old.  We’ve had more pods fail than Tslim site fails, but it’s a negligible amount.  But, I’ll step off that soapbox to reiterate that in the end, any pump is worth at least a shot if it means potentially better control and an easier life with diabetes.

My son is 11 and we were told while he is “well controlled” at 7+, he needs a pump to get better control. She stressed that it was literally the only way we would get his numbers looking better and he’s now on omnipod 5. It’s amazing. Not perfect, but he’s like 60% in range which I’ll take over the MDI while we get the hang of it ( he’s only been on the pump two weeks)

Look into the assistive device program, those are not the qualifications to get funding for a pump. 
Also I can only speak from my experience but give Medtronic( or other pump manufacturers a call) they do a great job helping you get one since the supplies is where they make their money
Get a different doctor. If you were in range majority of the time, you wouldn’t “need” a pump. A pump is meant to make diabetes treatment easier while still having a lot of control.

Oshawa Ontario here. I was told the only requirements are my son needs to be diabetic for a full year. His year is up so im doing a pump info session on the 25th then have a pump readiness appt July 4. I’d see a new dr
I totally agree with the consensus among the legends - get a new Endo. Yours is bananas.

I was so terrified to get a pump because my pediatric endocrinologist told me the same thing. I was also told that the complications would be worse if I was uncontrolled on a pump so I refused to go on one until last year and it was the best decision I ever made! 

I know endocrinologists are hard to come across (at least in the US), but definitely try to find a more supportive one. Getting on a pump can only improve your blood sugars if you’re using it correctly.

Good luck in your pump journey!
Mine told me to GET a pump because I’m less than 75% in range 🤷🏼‍♀️ like to help regulate I was told to try the pump. I haven’t yet but I will.
I get would get a  Dr . Mine tries to get me to go back on it every time I have an appointment no matter how much I tell him I didn't like it.
The pump was created to help us, not to make us feel like shit and jump through hoops to “earn” one. I’d get a new endo if possible.
My high A1C and multiple extreme lows made my insurance authorization happen within a few weeks. Basically comes down to having a doctor who know how to write the request form.

Im from toronto too and let me tell you the problem is your doctor. They would prescribe you the pump right away if you sugars arent being controlled in the good range. Cause that's basically getting on the pumps purpose is for.
What??? Like what others have said, you should find a different endocrinologist. I’m shocked that they said that.
You should get a new endo. I was in 30 percent range and they gave me a pump so I can have better control.
Thats absurd. I wasn't required to do anything for my pump.

The issue is that with a pump there’s more to troubleshoot if something goes wrong, more calculations to help on top of (although you should already be doing these to get as good control as possible).

I was put on a pump because I was consistently hypoing in the afternoon on 17 units of Lantus, but rose too much the rest of the day if I took 16 units.
In the uk there was some qualifying factor if you are having regular hypos that can’t be controlled with insulin alone (ie your basal dose requirements differ at different times of the day).

That is a wild “rule.” In my experience, assuming the person WANTS a pump (not everyone does, and I get it) a pump (especially tslim/Dexcom combo) is exponentially more successful in managing BG than injections simply because it’s so much quicker/easier to bolus and check bg levels.

I had 96% in range pre-pump (because I'm insane and obsessive - do not hold yourself to this standard) and my endo was like are you SURE you want a pump, you're doing so well with MDI and people usually want a pump with less-tight control. But for me, the pump lets me maintain that time in range without the mental load I was carrying (because I'm insane and obsessive) and has allowed me to chill the fuck out with my diabetes. It was a mental health thing for me more than anything. If there's a tool out there that will help you manage better - in any capacity - and your doctor is withholding it from you, then they are unreasonable and borderline unethical. ABSOLUTELY find a new doctor.

Hi fellow Ontarian! 👋 Sharing a bunch of info below. 

**TIPS FOR BG CONTROL**

Alright so I’m going to come from the angle of getting my A1c down to 4.9% during a recent pregnancy: 

- Document the shit out of everything while you’re waiting for your endo’s approval. If you’re on a Dexcom or Libre, I think you can enter your insulin doses or activities in the apps, but consider a separate app like MySugr or SugarMate (those two were my favourites) where you can include additional details like what you ate, illness, or what kind of activity you did. 
- Prebolus! Give that insulin at least 15 minutes before a meal unless you’re about to be physically active, then consider how active you’re going to be and adjust your timing and dose based on that. 
- Know how your body responds to different foods: pizza, fast food, and sushi tend to be difficult to give insulin for because of the delayed time for them to break down, so if you’re eating these, don’t jump in with your insulin too soon, but be prepared to need to give yourself a good dose of insulin to compensate for the tsunami of carbs. 
- If you’re finding a lot of highs/lows around exercise, take some time to research [ExCarbs](https://www.diabetesnet.com/diabetes-control/exercise-and-diabetes/excarbs-exercise/)… this page is full of crappy ads but the main content is good. The ExCarbs info is to help you figure out what level of exercise you’re doing and how much to either reduce insulin or increase carb intake by before your activity. 
- Try to find balance with your meals: protein, veg, and starch. Fibre. Try to avoid those breakfast options that spike your BG like oatmeal or Mini Wheats as it can set off your whole day.
- if you have a habit of looking at your phone while eating, make a cheeky little Lock Screen that says something like *“Sure you can eat that, but did you take your insulin for it?”*. Before I got on the CGM I had a reminder to get me to test my blood sugar that said “if you can scroll, you can test” and it helped keep me accountable to test 10-12 times a day, which brought my A1c down to about 6%. 
- If you’re interested in reading, try a copy of [The Book of Better](https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/0307720683/) or [Bright Spots and Landmines](https://www.amazon.ca/Bright-Spots-Landmines-Diabetes-Someone/dp/0692875174/).. I found these books both to be quite helpful. 
- Celebrate your wins, and don’t beat yourself up for a bad day; they happen to everyone.  


**MOHLTC ASSISTIVE DEVICES PROGRAM**

Qualifications for insulin pump and pump supply coverage through the Assistive Devices Program is available [here](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-support-for-diabetes-equipment-and-supplies). They’ll provide you with a pump and $2400 ($600 every 3 months) for pump supplies; anything *exceeding* that amount can be claimed on health insurances or as medical expenses for your taxes (with proof that you’ve exceeded the $2400/yr). 

Typically coverage is based on:
- You are an Ontario resident with an Ontario Health card
- You monitor your BG level at least 4 times a day (the CGM fulfills this requirement)
- You attend appointments at the recommended frequency of your endocrinologist (e.g., usually every 4-6 months)
- You have comprehension of carbohydrate counting, correction dosing, making adjustments if you’re sick, etc. 
- Number of highs/lows requiring third party intervention from family member or emergency services 
- Your HBA1c is 9% or below - note: this might not be a requirement anymore, but it still was when I was last approved 

Your clinic will complete the documentation for you; you may need to fill out the first section. You would also need to complete pump training where your diabetes educator and/or a representative from your preferred pump company would review how to use the pump (e.g., selecting an infusion site, inserting the set, filling your cartridge, setting your insulin rates such as basal rates, correction factors, insulin:carb ratio, syncing your CGM if you use one, learning about the “insulin on board” or active insulin, and reviewing other features like insulin suspension, creating new insulin setting programs, etc.) 

In my experience, an endo wants to see that you’re working toward meeting your goals because a pump isn’t a bandage solution to having good control. With that said, I’ve never heard of needing your time in range between 85-100%. 

Feel free to reach out if you have other questions; I’ve been on a pump (and covered by ADP) since 2002.

comments.text:
It‘s a general guideline, however, it has never worked for me (I take 70% basal). There are some neat articles about the general math: https://dtc.ucsf.edu/types-of-diabetes/type1/treatment-of-type-1-diabetes/medications-and-therapies/type-1-insulin-therapy/calculating-insulin-dose/

And overall treatment and why it is so different person to person (it can vary 0.5-1 unit per kilo!): https://www.aafp.org/pubs/afp/issues/1999/1115/p2343.html#references

Yea this is absurd, the basal rate is whatever keeps your glucose steady while fasting, which is completely independent of however much you bolus. And bolus amount is dependent on how many carbs you eat which varies from day to day, person to person by significant amounts. Def not current science.

I think it is also skewed with newer ultra-long acting insulins like tresiba. I've always had more bolus than basal, but when I moved to tresiba from levemir, it got even more skewed. I probably do 70 % bolus/30 % basal.

Lowering A1C
How are people able to lower their A1C to below 6 I am struggling to keep mine below 7. I exercise regularly and eat fairly well. My sugars are just a roller coaster. Going for a walk will make my sugars plummet even if I’ve turned my pump off an hour before.

What are people’s strategies?

comments.text: Maybe check your basals? I had the same problem with crazy numbers until my endo made me do a basal check. Found out some were high and some were too low.

For reference my A1C is 5.4% What’s your target fasting blood sugar? I shoot for 5, endo wants me at 5.5. Eat low carb-ish usually under 100g a day.
If I have a quick carb meal(potato or bread) it’s usually at lunchtime when I’m more sensitive. I pre-bolus for these meals 15-30 mins depending on what it is and how much. 
Eating low carb limits the roller coaster since you don’t have the huge hike and then the big crash, and limits margin for error, I have very few hypos.
I have a Dexcom CGM with range set 4.5-8.5 and it shows that I’m in range 98% of the time with 1%high and 1% low.

A libre CGM  has made a big difference for me and gives me the feedback. I have lowered my A1c. By 2 units and I’m at 6.0. 
Doing much better

Do you have a CGM? Just getting one lowered mine from 7 to 6.5-6.2. Going to a new dietitian low carb, grain free brought me to 5.6-5.8. Her name is Kelly Schmidt and she is type 1 herself, and helps other type 1s with their goals. She will meet with you through Skype. Just Google Kelly Schmidt diabetic dietitian and you will find her.

My goal on my pump is set to 95, so my corrections are calibrated to do so. My high goal is 120, so I aim to be less than 120. My Endocrinologists tell me I'm doing awesome but when I first told them I was doing low carb they did NOT support. 

I focus on gut health, because Diabetes is an autoimmune disease, healing the gut means avoiding gluten and inflammatory foods. I avoid dairy, soy, grains, carbs.
For me cereal isn’t worth it, I’ve tried prebolusing as much as 45 minutes before but the amount of quick carbs always puts me high. Bacon and eggs only! I’ll have a slice of toast occasionally.

this is something that I am well versed in. I have a number of strategies that work for me. 

I participate in endurance events call GORUCK Challenges. They are ball busters. What I try and do is stay consistent in my diet, my activity level, and also times of days that I do everything. 

I have found consistency is the key for me. Whatever you do, do it at the same times every day.
